and the members of the Board of
Inspection, Col. Elverton E. Fuller, Major J. J. Gerhardt and Major John E. McMahon, have expressed themselves as being exceeding well pleased with the
showing which th6 unit has made.
The program carried out yesterday and that which will hold
for the remainder of the inspection is as follows:
9.00-10.00 Monday—
'Fake board to North Point:

BALTIMORE, MD., MAY 2, 1922

THE BLACK SPOT UPON THE ORANGE
There appeared last week in the "Syracuse Orange" an editorial
lauding the good sportsmanship of the Oxford-Cambridge lacrosse
team and commenting in general upon clean athletics.
We have a suspicion that this edition of the "Orange" was
carefully concealed from the eyes of the gentlemen who visited us
at Homewood Field last Saturday.
It may be poor sportsmanship on our part to howl after losing
a game, but we have the satisfaction of knowing that no matter how
poor it may be, it is heavily overshadowed by the brand displayed
by the Syracuse lacrosse team.
As the game was not a league game, its result does not in any
way affect Hopkins' record. The game was intended to be an exhibition match. Just what was to be exhibited seems to have been
misunderstood by the Orange stickmen (or rather clubmen). What
was, exhibited was a contest marked by continuous disregard of
rules and their interpretation by the referee.

THE JOHNS HOPKINS NEWS-LETTER, APRIL 28, 1922
MECHANICAL ENGINEERS RECEIVE
NOTICE OF PRIZES

R. 0. T. C. MAKING GOOD
SHOWING

Last week the Hopkins student
:branch of the American Society
of Mechanical Engineers received
a notice from the headquarters announcing the establishment • of
two prizes for technical papers.
Through the generosity of a member of the society, two funds of
$1,000 each were established, the
income from which is to be awarded annually for the best paper by
a Junior member of the society,
and to the two enrolled student
branch members who contribute
the best papers. There are also a
number of other prizes and
awards. These include: Honorary
membership, life 'membership,
a medal for notable inventions,
and honorable mention for inventions or improvements in engineering.

WORK STARTED ON HANDBOOK

The staff of the Handbook has
already started work on next
year's "Freshman Bible." The editor of the new book, P. M.
Ghent, requests that all men in
the University will carefully look
over this year's Handbook to see
if anything of importance was
omitted or if any corrections are
to be made. Anyone having any
such corrections or any worthwhile suggestions to offer will
turn them in to Box 279. It is
important that this be done soon,
as the staff expects to send the
book to press before the close of
the school year.

A new plan is being tried out
in the Physical Training Class.
With the balmy spring days at
hand, the army calisthenics,
which had been in vogue all winter, began to grow irksome to the
students. A number of them, accordingly, went to Dr. Abercrombie and proposed a new plan—that
those students who desired be excused every Monday, Wednesday
and Friday afternoon to play baseball. After careful consideration,
Dr. Abercrombie realized that this
would be a good idea, and so gave
his official sanction to the plan.
The playing in the Physical
Training League will not be of the
."sandlot" variety, but will have
real "umps 'n everything." Those
students who wish to play will be
divided into teams and elaborate
schedules will be worked out.
Those who cannot play baseball
will continue with the army calisthenics. The division into baseball
teams does not separate the men
from the Physical Training Club,
but is carried on in conjunction
with it.
"Mike" Strouse, last year's star
third-baseman, who is prevented
from playing this year because of
scholastic difficulties, has been put
in charge. Dr. Abercrombie is trying to obtain as much equipment
as he possibly can for the men.
The purpose of this plan is to interest men in the game and thus
discover more material for the
Varsity.

DEPUTATION TEAM ON THE JOB

The Hopkins Deputation Team
has been on the job every Sunday
since February 12th, visiting seven churches and reaching about
seven hundred people. The services have been regular Sunday
evening church services.
Recently the team's quartette,
which has been adding much
to the services, sang at the Homewood M. E. Church, of which Dr.
Don Colt is in charge. He was
much interested in the work of
the team.
From now until the close of
school the team will hold two services each Sunday, most of them
being
held
in
out-of-town
churches.

BALTIMORE, MD., MAY 2, 1922

THE BLACK SPOT UPON THE ORANGE
There appeared last week in the "Syracuse Orange" an editorial
lauding the good sportsmanship of the Oxford-Cambridge lacrosse
team and commenting in general upon clean athletics.
We have a suspicion that this edition of the "Orange" was
carefully concealed from the eyes of the gentlemen who visited us
at Homewood Field last Saturday.
It may be poor sportsmanship on our part to howl after losing
a game, but we have the satisfaction of knowing that no matter how
poor it may be, it is heavily overshadowed by the brand displayed
by the Syracuse lacrosse team.
As the game was not a league game, its result does not in any
way affect Hopkins' record. The game was intended to be an exhibition match. Just what was to be exhibited seems to have been
misunderstood by the Orange stickmen (or rather clubmen). What
was, exhibited was a contest marked by continuous disregard of

MECHANICAL ENGINEERS RECEIVE
NOTICE OF PRIZES

R. 0. T. C. MAKING GOOD
SHOWING

Last week the Hopkins student
:branch of the American Society
of Mechanical Engineers received
a notice from the headquarters announcing the establishment • of
two prizes for technical papers.
Through the generosity of a member of the society, two funds of
$1,000 each were established, the
income from which is to be awarded annually for the best paper by
a Junior member of the society,
and to the two enrolled student
branch members who contribute
the best papers. There are also a
number of other prizes and
awards. These include: Honorary
membership, life 'membership,
a medal for notable inventions,
and honorable mention for inventions or improvements in engineering.

WORK STARTED ON HANDBOOK

The staff of the Handbook has
already started work on next
year's "Freshman Bible." The editor of the new book, P. M.
Ghent, requests that all men in
the University will carefully look
over this year's Handbook to see
if anything of importance was
omitted or if any corrections are
to be made. Anyone having any
such corrections or any worthwhile suggestions to offer will
turn them in to Box 279. It is
important that this be done soon,
as the staff expects to send the
book to press before the close of
the school year.

A new plan is being tried out
in the Physical Training Class.
With the balmy spring days at
hand, the army calisthenics,
which had been in vogue all winter, began to grow irksome to the
students. A number of them, accordingly, went to Dr. Abercrombie and proposed a new plan—that
those students who desired be excused every Monday, Wednesday
and Friday afternoon to play baseball. After careful consideration,
Dr. Abercrombie realized that this
would be a good idea, and so gave
his official sanction to the plan.
The playing in the Physical
Training League will not be of the
."sandlot" variety, but will have
real "umps 'n everything." Those
students who wish to play will be
divided into teams and elaborate
schedules will be worked out.
Those who cannot play baseball
will continue with the army calisthenics. The division into baseball
teams does not separate the men
from the Physical Training Club,
but is carried on in conjunction
with it.
"Mike" Strouse, last year's star
third-baseman, who is prevented
from playing this year because of
scholastic difficulties, has been put
in charge. Dr. Abercrombie is trying to obtain as much equipment
as he possibly can for the men.
The purpose of this plan is to interest men in the game and thus
discover more material for the
Varsity.

DEPUTATION TEAM ON THE JOB

The Hopkins Deputation Team
has been on the job every Sunday
since February 12th, visiting seven churches and reaching about
seven hundred people. The services have been regular Sunday
evening church services.
Recently the team's quartette,
which has been adding much
to the services, sang at the Homewood M. E. Church, of which Dr.
Don Colt is in charge. He was
much interested in the work of
the team.
From now until the close of
school the team will hold two services each Sunday, most of them
being
held
in
out-of-town
churches.
